texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: One of the first tools I learned about after working with Red Hat was  sysstat . It can write down historical records about your server at regular intervals. This can help you diagnose CPU usage, RAM usage, or network usage problems. In addition, sysstat also provides some handy command line utilities like  vmstat ,  iostat , and  pidstat  that give you a live view of what your system is doing.
texts.text: One of the first tools I learned about after working with Red Hat was  sysstat . It can write down historical records about your server at regular intervals. This can help you diagnose CPU usage, RAM usage, or network usage problems. In addition, sysstat also provides some handy command line utilities like  vmstat ,  iostat , and  pidstat  that give you a live view of what your system is doing.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: On Debian-based systems (including Ubuntu), you install the sysstat package and enable it with a quick edit to
texts.text: On Debian-based systems (including Ubuntu), you install the sysstat package and enable it with a quick edit to

texts.label: code
texts.orig: /etc/default/sysstat
texts.text: /etc/default/sysstat

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: and the cron job takes it from there. CentOS and Fedora systems call the collector process using a cron job in
texts.text: and the cron job takes it from there. CentOS and Fedora systems call the collector process using a cron job in

texts.label: code
texts.orig: /etc/cron.d
texts.text: /etc/cron.d

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: and it's enabled by default.
texts.text: and it's enabled by default.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Fedora 21 comes with sysstat 11 and there are now systemd unit files to control the collection and management of stats. You can find the unit files by listing the files in the sysstat RPM:
texts.text: Fedora 21 comes with sysstat 11 and there are now systemd unit files to control the collection and management of stats. You can find the unit files by listing the files in the sysstat RPM:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
$ rpm -ql sysstat | grep systemd
/usr/lib/systemd/system/sysstat-collect.service
/usr/lib/systemd/system/sysstat-collect.timer
/usr/lib/systemd/system/sysstat-summary.service
/usr/lib/systemd/system/sysstat-summary.timer
/usr/lib/systemd/system/sysstat.service
texts.text:
$ rpm -ql sysstat | grep systemd
/usr/lib/systemd/system/sysstat-collect.service
/usr/lib/systemd/system/sysstat-collect.timer
/usr/lib/systemd/system/sysstat-summary.service
/usr/lib/systemd/system/sysstat-summary.timer
/usr/lib/systemd/system/sysstat.service

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: These services and timers  aren't enabled by default  in Fedora 21. If you run
texts.text: These services and timers  aren't enabled by default  in Fedora 21. If you run

texts.label: code
texts.orig: sar
texts.text: sar

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: after installing sysstat, you'll see something like this:
texts.text: after installing sysstat, you'll see something like this:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# sar
Cannot open /var/log/sa/sa12: No such file or directory
Please check if data collecting is enabled
texts.text:
# sar
Cannot open /var/log/sa/sa12: No such file or directory
Please check if data collecting is enabled

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: All you need to do is enable and start the main sysstat service:
texts.text: All you need to do is enable and start the main sysstat service:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
systemctl enable sysstat
systemctl start sysstat
texts.text:
systemctl enable sysstat
systemctl start sysstat

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: From there, systemd will automatically call for collection and management of the statistics using its  internal timers . Opening up
texts.text: From there, systemd will automatically call for collection and management of the statistics using its  internal timers . Opening up

texts.label: code
texts.orig: /usr/lib/systemd/system/sysstat-collect.timer
texts.text: /usr/lib/systemd/system/sysstat-collect.timer

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: reveals the following:
texts.text: reveals the following:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# /usr/lib/systemd/system/sysstat-collect.timer
# (C) 2014 Tomasz Torcz <tomek@pipebreaker.pl>
#
# sysstat-11.0.0 systemd unit file:
#        Activates activity collector every 10 minutes

[Unit]
Description=Run system activity accounting tool every 10 minutes

[Timer]
OnCalendar=*:00/10

[Install]
WantedBy=sysstat.service
texts.text:
# /usr/lib/systemd/system/sysstat-collect.timer
# (C) 2014 Tomasz Torcz <tomek@pipebreaker.pl>
#
# sysstat-11.0.0 systemd unit file:
#        Activates activity collector every 10 minutes

[Unit]
Description=Run system activity accounting tool every 10 minutes

[Timer]
OnCalendar=*:00/10

[Install]
WantedBy=sysstat.service

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The timer unit file ensures that the sysstat-collect.service is called every 10 minutes based on the real time provided by the system clock. (There are other options to set timers based on relative time of when the server booted or when a user logged into the system). The familiar
texts.text: The timer unit file ensures that the sysstat-collect.service is called every 10 minutes based on the real time provided by the system clock. (There are other options to set timers based on relative time of when the server booted or when a user logged into the system). The familiar

texts.label: code
texts.orig: sa1
texts.text: sa1

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: command appears in
texts.text: command appears in

texts.label: code
texts.orig: /usr/lib/systemd/system/sysstat-collect.service
texts.text: /usr/lib/systemd/system/sysstat-collect.service

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# /usr/lib/systemd/system/sysstat-collect.service
# (C) 2014 Tomasz Torcz <tomek@pipebreaker.pl>
#
# sysstat-11.0.0 systemd unit file:
#        Collects system activity data
#        Activated by sysstat-collect.timer unit

[Unit]
Description=system activity accounting tool
Documentation=man:sa1(8)

[Service]
Type=oneshot
User=root
ExecStart=/usr/lib64/sa/sa1 1 1
texts.text:
# /usr/lib/systemd/system/sysstat-collect.service
# (C) 2014 Tomasz Torcz <tomek@pipebreaker.pl>
#
# sysstat-11.0.0 systemd unit file:
#        Collects system activity data
#        Activated by sysstat-collect.timer unit

[Unit]
Description=system activity accounting tool
Documentation=man:sa1(8)

[Service]
Type=oneshot
User=root
ExecStart=/usr/lib64/sa/sa1 1 1
